bibl.title: Letter from [John J. Moran] to Mrs. Dalmar R. Blakely, October 6, 1943

div1.p: [Moran] discusses his stay in the U.S., commenting on the changes that the war has had on American society. He thanks her for her hospitality she showed to his wife while he was at Walter Reed hospital.

div1.head: Letter from [John J. Moran] to Mrs. Dalmar R. Blakely, October 6, 1943
div1.p:
Here we are, back in Havana once more,
after the most eventful trip I can recall, to God's
Country, since I became a tropical tramp some forty
years ago. I thought I had a fairly decent mental
picture of what our all-out war effort meant on the
home front, as we could visualize it from this “Gem of
the Sea”, but I was very far off. A little over a month
in God's Country convinced me, as no word picture could,
of the profound change in American life and thought that
this world conflict has brought about. While I was a
patient at Walter Reed Hospital I saw many examples of the
cruel results of armed conflict in the maimed and dismember-
ed physical wrecks among the youth of our land. It made my
heart bleed and left me with an impression so profound that
to forget it would be impossible.

By the same token, neither Elida nor your
humble servant can ever forget your hospitality and kindness
to my better half while se was a guest at the Hostess House
over which you preside with such dignity, tact and efficiency.
I want you to know that we are both most grateful to you. If,
in the coming years, you should decide to visit Cuba, it would
indeed be a privilege to reciprocate in part your kindness and
consideration to us both during the eleven days I was a patient
at the Hospital. Elida has always been timid but from the very
first day she lost her timidity with you. Your winning ways,
inherent and natural, disarmed her completely.

Please remember us kindly to Miss Louhi, when
and as you may see her. She was an excellent disciple of yours.
Also, should an opportunity present itself, please remember me
to General Marietta.
div1.closer:
Yours very sincerely, Mrs. Dalmar R. Blakely,
Hostess House,
Walter Reed General Hospital,
Army Medical Center,
Washington, D. C.
Our address:
c/o Cia. Sunoco de Cuba, S. A.,
Ave. Menocal Nos. 455-457.
HAVANA, CUBA.
